Hi: How do I change the PATH to look for /usr/local/bin first?
Can anyone help me please?
/usr/local/bin has to appear in the list of directories in PATH first
after changing PATH, if a shell is already running, you have to do    hash -r     in the shell
usually you edit $HOME/.bashrc
if your path is already there, you can change it
if your path isn't there, or you don't have a $HOME/.bashrc yet, then you can do this:
echo $PATH > some-file-name
that gets the current path into a file.  Then you can edit it into .bashrc, then adjust it.
if you don't have a $HOME/.bashrc, then create one.
in the file you want:     export PATH=/whatever ...
that's ok.  look for a line beginning with     export PATH=
no, it's not a bios issue
so what is it?
could be a slight misalignment between the burner and the cd reader.  I have seen a couple of cases of this type of behavior that were fixed by using the proper jumper settings for the drive.
specifically, if the drive is connected with an EIDE cable, make sure it's jumpered for cable select
it's not impossible that switching DMA off (in the BIOS setting for the drive) would help, but the odds aren't great.
tell him to try burning the CD at the lowest available speed setting, say 4x.
that's what he did :P
I mean he burned it at 4x
